column1: • Carolina K-12
<title>Carolina Public Humanities is the outreach arm of UNC's College of Arts & Sciences. We offer various types of events that are open to the public. </title>

Embodying the university’s mission to extend the resources of the University to all citizens and community members of North Carolina, Carolina Public Humanities offers engaging and innovative public seminars and lectures on a variety of topics and themes throughout the year. Our programs draw upon the humanities to nurture a deeper understanding of history and culture, enrich the life of the mind, and contribute to the development of a more humane world. To learn more about our upcoming events and access registration information, visit Programs.
Explore Our K-12 Resources

Carolina K-12, Carolina Public Humanities’ teacher outreach project, offers quality professional development programs and curriculum to North Carolina educators. Our teacher-centered events include access to scholars on key topics, innovative lesson plans, and interactive pedagogical training. We also offer an online Database of K-12 Resources, featuring hundreds of ready-to-implement lessons, Power Points and activities. To learn more about our opportunities for teachers and to browse our K-12 resources, click here.

Our programs would not be possible without your generous support. Gifts of all sizes help ensure our programs remain accessible, providing all North Carolinian’s access to engaging scholarship and quality opportunities for life-long learning at Carolina. In addition, private funds are crucial in supporting the high-quality professional development and curriculum we provide at no cost for our state’s K-12 teachers. For more information regarding giving to the Program, or to inquire about volunteer opportunities, click here.

Kalleberg, Kenan Distinguished Professor of Sociology Major changes have engulfed the employment systems in virtually all advanced capitalist nations. Work has become more uncertain, unstable and insecure, and workers receive fewer social benefits.
